english: Embarrassing; to feel ashamed or self-conscious about oneself or a situation.
japanese_example: <ruby>人前<rt>ひとまえ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>転<rt>ころ</rt></ruby>んで、とても<ruby>恥<rt>は</rt></ruby>ずかしかった。
english_example: I fell in front of everyone, and it was very embarrassing.

english: Explanatory copula used to add explanation or emphasis; often feels like “it is that…” or “the thing is…”.
japanese_example: <ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby><ruby>忙<rt>いそが</rt></ruby>しいのだ。
english_example: The thing is, I'm busy right now.

english: Supremely; exceedingly; “as ~ as possible,” typically modifying adjectives or adverbs.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>この上<rt>このうえ</rt></ruby>なく<ruby>幸<rt>しあわ</rt></ruby>せそうだった。
english_example: He looked supremely happy.

english: Birdcage; a cage for keeping birds.
japanese_example: <ruby>鳥籠<rt>とりかご</rt></ruby>の<ruby>中<rt>なか</rt></ruby>で<ruby>小鳥<rt>ことり</rt></ruby>が<ruby>鳴<rt>な</rt></ruby>いている。
english_example: A little bird is chirping inside the birdcage.

english: To lock up or confine; to shut someone or something inside so they cannot get out.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>怒<rt>おこ</rt></ruby>りを<ruby>心<rt>こころ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>中<rt>なか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>閉<rt>と</rt></ruby>じ<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>めた。
english_example: He locked his anger away inside his heart.

english: Verb suffix meaning “into” or “thoroughly,” often implying entering deep inside or doing something completely.
japanese_example: <ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>ってきたので、<ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>駆<rt>か</rt></ruby>け<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: When it started to rain, I dashed into the house.

english: Padlock; a portable lock typically used with a chain or latch.
japanese_example: <ruby>門<rt>もん</rt></ruby>に<ruby>南京錠<rt>なんきんじょう</rt></ruby>がかかっていた。
english_example: A padlock was fastened on the gate.

english: Up to/until; can also mean “even” to emphasize an extreme or unexpected example.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>水<rt>みず</rt></ruby>まで<ruby>買<rt>か</rt></ruby>い<ruby>忘<rt>わす</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: He even forgot to buy water.

english: Listing form used to give examples of actions/states; often paired as 〜たり〜たりする to mean “do things like…”.
japanese_example: <ruby>休日<rt>きゅうじつ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>本<rt>ほん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>読<rt>よ</rt></ruby>んだり<ruby>散歩<rt>さんぽ</rt></ruby>したりする。
english_example: On my days off, I do things like read books and take walks.

english: Body/physique, often implying a big, hulking build; can sound slightly rude or blunt.
japanese_example: <ruby>図体<rt>ずうたい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>大<rt>おお</rt></ruby>きいのに、<ruby>動<rt>うご</rt></ruby>きは<ruby>意外<rt>いがい</rt></ruby>と<ruby>静<rt>しず</rt></ruby>かだ。
english_example: Even though he's huge, his movements are surprisingly quiet.

english: Neck; also used in set phrases (and can mean “head” or “job” in some contexts).
japanese_example: <ruby>首<rt>くび</rt></ruby>がこっているので、<ruby>少<rt>すこ</rt></ruby>し<ruby>回<rt>まわ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: My neck is stiff, so I rotated it a bit.

english: To sink into or become embedded; used for something pressing in deeply.
japanese_example: <ruby>石<rt>いし</rt></ruby>が<ruby>土<rt>つち</rt></ruby>に<ruby>めり込<rt>めりこ</rt></ruby>んで<ruby>取<rt>と</rt></ruby>れない。
english_example: The stone is embedded in the soil and won't come out.

english: To stand out; to be conspicuous or noticeable (often visually).
japanese_example: <ruby>あの</ruby><ruby>赤<rt>あか</rt></ruby>い<ruby>帽子<rt>ぼうし</rt></ruby>はとても<ruby>目立<rt>めだ</rt></ruby>つ。
english_example: That red hat really stands out.

english: Moustache; hair above the upper lip.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>口髭<rt>くちひげ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>伸<rt>の</rt></ruby>ばし<ruby>始<rt>はじ</rt></ruby>めた。
english_example: He started growing a moustache.

english: To become emaciated/gaunt; suggests being extremely thin in an unhealthy-looking way.
japanese_example: <ruby>長<rt>なが</rt></ruby>い<ruby>入院<rt>にゅういん</rt></ruby>で<ruby>痩<rt>や</rt></ruby>せこけてしまった。
english_example: After a long hospital stay, he became gaunt.

english: Small/petite build; describes a person’s stature and frame.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>小柄<rt>こがら</rt></ruby>だが、とても<ruby>力<rt>ちから</rt></ruby>が<ruby>強<rt>つよ</rt></ruby>い。
english_example: She has a petite build, but she's very strong.

english: Slender build; describes someone thin and narrow-framed (often neutral or positive).
japanese_example: <ruby>兄<rt>あに</rt></ruby>は<ruby>細身<rt>ほそみ</rt></ruby>で、<ruby>服<rt>ふく</rt></ruby>がよく<ruby>似合<rt>にあ</rt></ruby>う。
english_example: My older brother has a slender build, and clothes look good on him.

english: Te-form of the copula used to connect nouns/な-adjectives: “being …, and … / because …”; links clauses smoothly.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>学生<rt>がくせい</rt></ruby>で、<ruby>夜<rt>よる</rt></ruby>は<ruby>働<rt>はたら</rt></ruby>いている。
english_example: He is a student, and he works at night.

english: Radiance; shine; the noun form of 輝く, referring to a gleam or brilliance.
japanese_example: <ruby>朝日<rt>あさひ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>輝<rt>かがや</rt></ruby>きが<ruby>海<rt>うみ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>映<rt>うつ</rt></ruby>っていた。
english_example: The radiance of the morning sun was reflected on the sea.

english: Crumpled or messy; a な-adjective used for wrinkled paper/clothes or a disheveled look.
japanese_example: <ruby>くしゃくしゃ</ruby>な<ruby>紙<rt>かみ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>伸<rt>の</rt></ruby>ばして<ruby>読<rt>よ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: I smoothed out the crumpled paper and read it.

english: Pitch-black; deep black; emphasizes the intensity of blackness.
japanese_example: <ruby>空<rt>そら</rt></ruby>が<ruby>真<rt>ま</rt></ruby>っ<ruby>黒<rt>くろ</rt></ruby>になって、<ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: The sky turned pitch-black, and it started to rain.

english: Hair; used for hair on the head (contrast: 毛 for body hair/fur in many contexts).
japanese_example: <ruby>髪<rt>かみ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>短<rt>みじか</rt></ruby>く<ruby>切<rt>き</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: I cut my hair short.

english: Forehead; the front upper part of the face.
japanese_example: <ruby>額<rt>ひたい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>汗<rt>あせ</rt></ruby>がにじんだ。
english_example: Sweat beaded on my forehead.

english: Faintly; lightly; describes something weakly visible or present.
japanese_example: <ruby>山<rt>やま</rt></ruby>が<ruby>霧<rt>きり</rt></ruby>の<ruby>中<rt>なか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>うっすら</ruby>と<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: The mountains were faintly visible in the mist.

english: Lightning-shaped; used to describe something with a zigzag lightning-bolt shape.
japanese_example: <ruby>額<rt>ひたい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>稲妻形<rt>いなずまがた</rt></ruby>の<ruby>傷痕<rt>きずあと</rt></ruby>があった。
english_example: There was a lightning-shaped scar on his forehead.

english: Shape; form; the outline or configuration of something.
japanese_example: <ruby>この</ruby><ruby>雲<rt>くも</rt></ruby>は<ruby>星<rt>ほし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>形<rt>かたち</rt></ruby>に<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>える。
english_example: This cloud looks like the shape of a star.

english: Scar; a mark left after a wound has healed (more specific than 傷).
japanese_example: <ruby>古<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>い<ruby>傷痕<rt>きずあと</rt></ruby>が<ruby>腕<rt>うで</rt></ruby>に<ruby>残<rt>のこ</rt></ruby>っている。
english_example: An old scar remains on my arm.

english: Wound or injury; a general term for damage to the body or to objects.
japanese_example: <ruby>指<rt>ゆび</rt></ruby>に<ruby>傷<rt>きず</rt></ruby>ができたので<ruby>絆創膏<rt>ばんそうこう</rt></ruby>を<ruby>貼<rt>は</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: I got a cut on my finger, so I put on a bandage.

english: Special; exceptional; can describe something out of the ordinary or reserved for certain cases.
japanese_example: <ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>特別<rt>とくべつ</rt></ruby>な<ruby>日<rt>ひ</rt></ruby>だから、<ruby>外食<rt>がいしょく</rt></ruby>しよう。
english_example: Since today is a special day, let's eat out.

english: The wizarding world; a fictional society/world of magic users.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>突然<rt>とつぜん</rt></ruby><ruby>魔法界<rt>まほうかい</rt></ruby>の<ruby>存在<rt>そんざい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He suddenly learned of the existence of the wizarding world.

english: Emphatic “even”; highlights that something is true even for an extreme or unexpected case.
japanese_example: <ruby>子供<rt>こども</rt></ruby>でさえ<ruby>分<rt>わ</rt></ruby>かる<ruby>説明<rt>せつめい</rt></ruby>にしてほしい。
english_example: I want an explanation that even a child can understand.

english: Riddle; mystery; something puzzling that requires an explanation.
japanese_example: <ruby>その</ruby><ruby>出来事<rt>できごと</rt></ruby>は<ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby>も<ruby>謎<rt>なぞ</rt></ruby>のままだ。
english_example: That incident is still a mystery.

english: To wrap or cover; can be literal (wrapping) or figurative (being enveloped).
japanese_example: <ruby>荷物<rt>にもつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>紙<rt>かみ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>包<rt>つつ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: I wrapped the package in paper.

english: Only; unique; emphasizes that there is just one (唯一の〜).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>唯一<rt>ゆいいつ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>理解者<rt>りかいしゃ</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: He is my only person who truly understands me.

english: Clue; lead; information or a hint used to solve a problem or mystery.
japanese_example: <ruby>小<rt>ちい</rt></ruby>さな<ruby>手<rt>て</rt></ruby>がかりを<ruby>頼<rt>たよ</rt></ruby>りに<ruby>犯人<rt>はんにん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>探<rt>さが</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: Using a small clue as a lead, we searched for the culprit.

english: Doorway; entrance; the area at the door (not the door itself).
japanese_example: <ruby>戸口<rt>とぐち</rt></ruby>に<ruby>誰<rt>だれ</rt></ruby>かが<ruby>立<rt>た</rt></ruby>っていた。
english_example: Someone was standing in the doorway.

english: Leaving behind; abandonment; typically used as 置き去りにする or 置き去りにされる.
japanese_example: <ruby>駅<rt>えき</rt></ruby>に<ruby>荷物<rt>にもつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>き<ruby>去<rt>ざ</rt></ruby>りにしてしまった。
english_example: I ended up leaving my luggage behind at the station.

english: To abandon or leave behind; to go away without taking someone or something along.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>友達<rt>ともだち</rt></ruby>を<ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>き<ruby>去<rt>ざ</rt></ruby>りにして<ruby>先<rt>さき</rt></ruby>に<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He left his friend behind and went ahead.

english: Passive: to be abandoned or left behind by someone; focuses on the person/object left.
japanese_example: <ruby>暗<rt>くら</rt></ruby>い<ruby>道<rt>みち</rt></ruby>で<ruby>一人<rt>ひとり</rt></ruby><ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>き<ruby>去<rt>ざ</rt></ruby>りにされた。
english_example: I was left behind alone on a dark road.

english: Past passive: “was abandoned/was left behind”; a completed instance of 置き去りにされる.
japanese_example: <ruby>戸口<rt>とぐち</rt></ruby>に<ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>き<ruby>去<rt>ざ</rt></ruby>りにされた<ruby>箱<rt>はこ</rt></ruby>があった。
english_example: There was a box that had been left behind in the doorway.

english: Reason; cause; an explanation for why something happened or is the case.
japanese_example: <ruby>遅刻<rt>ちこく</rt></ruby>した<ruby>理由<rt>りゆう</rt></ruby>を<ruby>説明<rt>せつめい</rt></ruby>してください。
english_example: Please explain the reason you were late.

english: To know; to learn or find out (often becomes stative as 知っている for “know”).
japanese_example: <ruby>その</ruby><ruby>事実<rt>じじつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>ったとき、<ruby>驚<rt>おどろ</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: When I learned that fact, I was surprised.

english: In history; of all time; used in phrases like 史上最大 or 史上最強 to compare historically.
japanese_example: <ruby>それ</ruby>は<ruby>史上<rt>しじょう</rt></ruby><ruby>最大<rt>さいだい</rt></ruby>の<ruby>失敗<rt>しっぱい</rt></ruby>だと<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>われた。
english_example: It was said to be the biggest failure in history.

english: Strongest; most powerful; often used in comparisons like 史上最強.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>史上<rt>しじょう</rt></ruby><ruby>最強<rt>さいきょう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>選手<rt>せんしゅ</rt></ruby>だと<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>われている。
english_example: He is said to be the strongest athlete of all time.

english: Darkness; also used figuratively for secrecy or the underworld.
japanese_example: <ruby>闇<rt>やみ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>中<rt>なか</rt></ruby>で<ruby>足音<rt>あしおと</rt></ruby>だけが<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>こえた。
english_example: In the darkness, only footsteps could be heard.

english: Wizard; magician; a person who uses magic (general term).
japanese_example: <ruby>魔法使<rt>まほうつか</rt></ruby>いが<ruby>杖<rt>つえ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>振<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>って<ruby>光<rt>ひかり</rt></ruby>を<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: The wizard waved a wand and produced light.

english: Witch; a female magic user, and also used in folklore contexts.
japanese_example: <ruby>森<rt>もり</rt></ruby>に<ruby>住<rt>す</rt></ruby>む<ruby>魔女<rt>まじょ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: I heard a story about a witch who lives in the forest.

english: Title meaning “lord” or “sir”; an honorific used in formal or stylized contexts.
japanese_example: <ruby>公爵卿<rt>こうしゃくきょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>静<rt>しず</rt></ruby>かに<ruby>席<rt>せき</rt></ruby>に<ruby>着<rt>つ</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: The duke took his seat quietly.

english: Curse; a spell or malediction that brings misfortune or harm.
japanese_example: <ruby>古<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>い<ruby>呪<rt>のろ</rt></ruby>いが<ruby>村<rt>むら</rt></ruby>を<ruby>包<rt>つつ</rt></ruby>んでいると<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>われた。
english_example: It was said that an old curse was enveloping the village.

english: To break (rules/promise) or to tear (paper); also used as “to defeat” in some contexts.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>約束<rt>やくそく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>破<rt>やぶ</rt></ruby>ってしまった。
english_example: He ended up breaking his promise.

english: To remain; to be left over; describes something still existing after others are gone or used up.
japanese_example: <ruby>会議<rt>かいぎ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>後<rt>あと</rt></ruby>、<ruby>部屋<rt>へや</rt></ruby>に<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>だけが<ruby>残<rt>のこ</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: After the meeting, only I remained in the room.

english: To survive; to remain alive (often after danger or disaster), and can also mean “survive” in competition.
japanese_example: <ruby>事故<rt>じこ</rt></ruby>から<ruby>生<rt>い</rt></ruby>き<ruby>残<rt>のこ</rt></ruby>った<ruby>人<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>は<ruby>少<rt>すく</rt></ruby>なかった。
english_example: Few people survived the accident.

english: To live through and make it out alive; emphasizes enduring a difficult period or situation.
japanese_example: <ruby>厳<rt>きび</rt></ruby>しい<ruby>冬<rt>ふゆ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>生<rt>い</rt></ruby>き<ruby>延<rt>の</rt></ruby>びるために<ruby>食料<rt>しょくりょう</rt></ruby>を<ruby>蓄<rt>たくわ</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: To live through the harsh winter, we stored food.

english: Still; even now; indicates a situation has not changed despite time passing.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>いまだに</ruby><ruby>その</ruby><ruby>名前<rt>なまえ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>覚<rt>おぼ</rt></ruby>えている。
english_example: He still remembers that name even now.

english: To fear; to be afraid of; somewhat formal compared with 怖がる.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>失敗<rt>しっぱい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>恐<rt>おそ</rt></ruby>れて<ruby>挑戦<rt>ちょうせん</rt></ruby>しなかった。
english_example: He feared failure and didn't take on the challenge.

english: Passive: to be attacked or assaulted; the subject is the one who suffers the attack.
japanese_example: <ruby>夜道<rt>よみち</rt></ruby>で<ruby>襲<rt>おそ</rt></ruby>われて、<ruby>財布<rt>さいふ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>取<rt>と</rt></ruby>られた。
english_example: I was attacked on a dark street at night and had my wallet taken.

english: To attack or assault; an active verb describing the aggressor’s action.
japanese_example: <ruby>突然<rt>とつぜん</rt></ruby><ruby>犬<rt>いぬ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>襲<rt>おそ</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: Suddenly, a dog attacked him.
